acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data. As relevant information, all 10 animals died at 5000 mg/kg (PATTY (5th, 2001)).

aspiration_hazard.rationale: Although the substance is a hydrocarbon, classification was not possible since the kinematic viscosity at 40 degC was unknown.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data.

explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified into Category 3 since flash point 57 degC (closed-cup) (HSDB (2003)) is >=23 degC and <=60 degC. The substance is classified into Class 3, PG III in UNRTDG (UN2049).

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: No data available. For health hazards, refer also to the information of 1,4-diethylbenzene (CAS 105-05-5).

organic_peroxides.rationale: Organic compounds containing no bivalent -O-O- structure

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing no oxygen, fluorine or chlorine

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Auto-ignition point is 395 degC (Lide (88th, 2008)) exceeding 70 degC.

reproductive_toxicity.rationale:
No data available.
Refer also to the information of 1,4-diethylbenzene (CAS 105-05-5).

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Diethylbenzene tested by drop on a rabbit eye caused transient symptoms of irritation, but no injury was detected by fluorescein staining (HSDB (2003)). Additionally, it was reported that men exposed to 1000 ppm experienced eye irritation which rapidly diminished in intensity on continued exposure and a concentration of 2000 ppm caused immediately severe eye irritation, lacrimation (HSDB (2003)), and there is a report that diethylbenzene is an eye irritant (HSDB (2003)). Based on these information, the substance was classified into Category 2. [Data for diethylbenzene was used as the basis of classification on the assumption that there are only minor differences between isomers.]

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: No data available. For health hazards, refer also to 1,4-diethylbenzene (CAS 105-05-5).

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (central nervous system)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: The effects of 1,2-diethylbenzene on brainstem auditory evoked potentials (BAEPs) were studied in rats administered 75 or 100 mg/kg/day orally for 8 weeks (90-day equivalence: approximately 40 - 60 mg/kg/day) (HSDB (2003)). The administration was associated with severe hindlimb weakness and gait disturbances and increases in peak latencies, decreases in amplitude of all five components of the BAEP and prolonged interpeak latencies. Therefore, it was concluded that the substance is toxic to the central nervous system and the observed effects on the BAEP indicate that the substance induces functional alterations in the auditory pathways (HSDB (2003)). Since this result was observed at dosing levels within the guidance value range for Category 2 with oral route, the substance was classified into Category 2 (central nervous system). As relevant information, refer also to the information of 1,4-diethylbenzene (CAS 105-05-5).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale:
Although there is a report that slight hemorrhage and dystrophic change were observed in the liver, gastric mucosa, duodenum, spleen and kidney following oral application of isomer mixture to rats (PATTY (5th, 2001)), classification was not possible due to lack of data for the substance itself rather than isomer mixture.
For health hazards, refer also to the information of 1,4-diethylbenzene (CAS 105-05-5).
